head.headtext: Chemical tests of bodily fluids—Blood tests—Paternity

para.paratext: Evidence from blood tests is relevant and widely used in child support,[1] paternity, and abandonment proceedings. Parentage-determination testing includes, but is not limited to, red cell antigen, human leukocyte antigen (HLA), red cell enzyme, and serum protein electrophoresis tests or testing by deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) probes.[2]

The court, upon motion of the petitioner, the respondent, or any interested party, may order the mother, the alleged father, and the child to submit to any blood tests which are reasonably accessible.[3] If the action is brought prior to the birth of the child, the court must order any blood tests be made as soon as medically feasible after the birth.[4] The tests are to be performed by a duly qualified, licensed, practicing physician, immunologist, or other person.[5]

The test results are to be made known to all parties at interest as soon as available,[6] and the results of court-ordered medical tests and comparisons, including the statistical likelihood of parentage, must be admitted in evidence when offered by a duly qualified, licensed practicing physician, immunologist, geneticist, or other person.[7] A scientifically credible parentage-determination genetic test, which establishes at least a 97% probability of paternity, creates a rebuttable presumption of paternity of a child born out of wedlock.[8]
Decisions of paternity are made by the court. Parties to an action to establish paternity are not entitled to a trial by jury.[9]

An order to submit to blood tests in a paternity case is enforceable by contempt, and, if the petitioner (father) refuses to submit to a blood test, the court may dismiss the action upon motion of the respondent.[10] Evidence of a refusal to submit to a blood test or other ordered medical or anthropological test is admissible to show that the alleged father is not precluded from being the father of the child.[11]

See Rainwater v. State, 210 Ga. App. 594, 436 S.E.2d 772 (1993) (paternity test results showing 99.07% probability that defendant was father of child was relevant in prosecution for abandonment to demonstrate defendant's motive and intent in failing to pay support after receiving notice).

However, the failure to obtain a court order for the blood test does not render the results of the blood test inadmissible. O.C.G.A. § 19-7-46 does not preclude the admission of test results not ordered by the court, if a proper foundation is laid for admission. See Smith v. Department of Human Resources, 226 Ga. App. 491, 487 S.E.2d 94 (1997).

If a petition is brought before the birth of the child, all proceedings shall be stayed until after the birth except service of process, discovery, and the taking of depositions. O.C.G.A. § 19-7-43(c).
Regarding abandonment proceedings in which the question of parentage arises, see O.C.G.A. § 19-10-1.

Trial court excluded report showing paternity blood test results and testimony from expert witness as to his conclusions based on excluded document. O.C.G.A. § 19-7-46(a) sanctions admission of results of scientifically reliable testing conducted by qualified persons. It does not eliminate or modify hearsay rule with respect to admission of such test results. Since results of individual tests are not part of record, court was unable to determine if test results from which report was compiled contained opinions or conclusions of third parties who conducted tests, or whether individual tests simply yielded information not subject to hearsay objection from which Department of Human Resources expert reached his own conclusions and opinions. Department of Human Resources v. Corbin, 202 Ga. App. 10, 413 S.E.2d 484 (1991).

Results of HLA tests indicated that appellant could not have been child's father. Because there was at least some basis upon which juror could have discounted results of HLA testing as being unreliable, they were authorized to reject those test results and to rely instead on other evidence tending to show that appellant was child's father. Williamson v. Ward, 192 Ga. App. 857, 386 S.E.2d 727 (1989).

Until jury makes decision that tests were properly conducted and expert presenting results testified truthfully, test results are not entitled to any greater deference than any other evidence of paternity. Howard v. Howard, 258 Ga. 846, 375 S.E.2d 852 (1989).
O.C.G.A. § 19-7-40(a); see also Banks v. Hopson, 275 Ga. 758, 571 S.E.2d 730 (2002).
